newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Mid-Atlantic spot power firm on warm weather.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Mid-Atlantic spot power firm on warm weather.

text.p: U.S. Mid-Atlantic spot electricity prices were firm Tuesday on forecasts of warmer than normal weather in the region next week, brokers and marketers said.
"It'll be a little warmer next week," said one East Coast power trader.

In the Pennsylvania-New Jersey-Maryland (PJM) Interconnect power pool, firm, peak electricity prices for Wednesday delivery were quoted at $21.00-$23.00, compared with Monday's $22.50-$23.50 per megawatt hour (MWh) for Tuesday delivery, brokers and traders said.
Off-peak PJM power for next-day delivery was notionally pegged at $13.50-$15.50, compared with Monday's $14.50-$15.50.

PJM electricity for the next three business days was valued at $21.00-$21.50, down from Tuesday's $22.25-$23.00 for four days. Next-week PJM power was quoted at $21.50-$22.50 with a deal heard transacted at $22.00.
September PJM power for firm, peak delivery was pegged at $21.50-$22.50 after a sale was reportedly done at $21.25, compared with $21.75-$22.10 on Monday.
October PJM prices, under same delivery conditions, were discussed at $22.25-$22.50, unchanged from Monday.
Firm, peak PJM electricity for November delivery was quoted at $21.35-$21.55, and for December $25.00-$25.50. November's and December's values were flat from Monday.

PJM firm, peak power for the fourth quarter of 1996 was talked at $22.25-$22.40, near unchanged from Monday's $22.30-$22.50. First-quarter 1997 PJM prices were assessed at $27.30-$27.80, also flat from Monday.
